Award.AwardTitle: Facility Support: Accelerator Mass Spectrometry at PRIME Lab
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Purdue Rare Isotope Measurement Laboratory (PRIME Lab) routinely measures 10Be, 26Al, 36Cl and 129I in rock, soil, water, and air for a large community of NSF-sponsored and other users providing i) state-of-the-art measurements for routinely-utilized radionuclides for the NSF user community, ii) chemical preparation services for those NSF investigators who do not have their own in-house laboratories or expertise, iii) new measurement techniques that will be used in future geoscience investigations, and iv) NSF geoscience investigators with the knowledge needed to apply radionuclides to geoscience problems. The measurement of radionuclides by accelerator mass spectrometry (AMS) is an essential component of the study of Earth surface processes and Quaternary geology. These radionuclides are used to date landforms, fluids, and sediments, and to determine rates of erosion, soil formation, and tectonic deformation, geologic processes that directly impact human populations.

These measurements are reported in hundreds of scientific reports published in numerous internationally recognized journals. We are actively engaged in teaching sample preparation methods to the next generation of researchers, independent of their affiliation. PRIME Lab also employs numerous undergraduate Purdue University students, teaching them the basics of data acquisition and data analysis. PRIME Lab plays a significant role in the larger education community in the West Lafayette area. Working together with the College of Science counselor and the Department of Physics Outreach Director, PRIME Lab hosts hundreds of students annually on laboratory tours.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Accelerator mass spectrometry (AMS) is applied to a diverse range of research problems spanning numerous earth science disciplines.  The unique strength of AMS is its ability to measure isotopes of an element at abundance ratios from 10-12 to <10-16. The nuclides most commonly measured by AMS include 10Be, 14C, 26Al, 36Cl, and 129I. These and other radionuclides are produced in a variety of geologic settings; they serve as chronometers or tracers of naturally-occurring processes. For the last 20 years the number of papers utilizing these radionuclides has grown from a few dozen to more than 250 annually (exclusive of radiocarbon), with a substantial fraction containing PRIME Lab data. These publications span many disciplines, including hydrology, glacial chronology, volcanology, meteoritics and planetary science, geomorphology, landscape evolution, tectonic geomorphology, and paleoseismology.  An increasing number of papers are also appearing in the fields of archaeology and paleoanthropology. The growing number of publications evinces an enthusiastic recognition of the utility and necessity of AMS measurements as a key component in the geosciences. 

PRIME Lab is the only university-based AMS laboratory in the US that offers the full range of measurements for radionuclides and also offers chemical preparation facilities and expertise for most sample matrices.

In the last several years we have completed the initial development of the gas-filled-magnet. This has improved the performance of the AMS system for 10Be, 26Al, and 36Cl. The new capability has enabled us to attack new problems. We are just beginning to explore these new capabilities for geoscience problems.
